page.title: 08Housing In Bawdeswell
page.content: Bawdeswell was named in the Domesday Book as Baldersuella and was mentioned in Chaucer's Canterbury Tales, hence the carving of the Reeve on the village sign ( the last one made by Harry Carter of Swaffham before his death in 1983 ). The half-timbered Chaucer House, said to have been the home of the poet's uncle, is the oldest dwelling. Some 19'th century houses, built when B'well was part of the Holkham estate, are of sandstone from Holkham and brick from a local kiln. 235 homes include modern estate types, many of them bungalows, costing between Â£25000 & Â£30000, 61 are council houses, Folland Court is a complex of council group homes for the elderly. The remains of a smithy still survive. The largest residence is Bawdeswell Hall, dating from 1633, home of the Gurney Family.
